azuread-datasource-azuread-application.body:
data "azuread_application" "$1" {
    # object_id - (Optional) Specifies the Object ID of the Application within Azure Active Directory.
    object_id = ""

    # name - (Optional) Specifies the name of the Application within Azure Active Directory.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - the Object ID of the Azure Active Directory Application.
    # "application_id" - the Application ID of the Azure Active Directory Application.
    # "available_to_other_tenants" - Is this Azure AD Application available to other tenants?
    # "identifier_uris" - A list of user-defined URI(s) that uniquely identify a Web application within it's Azure AD tenant, or within a verified custom domain if the application is multi-tenant.
    # "oauth2_allow_implicit_flow" - Does this Azure AD Application allow OAuth2.0 implicit flow tokens?
    # "object_id" - the Object ID of the Azure Active Directory Application.
    # "reply_urls" - A list of URLs that user tokens are sent to for sign in, or the redirect URIs that OAuth 2.0 authorization codes and access tokens are sent to.
}
azuread-datasource-azuread-application.description: Use this data source to access information about an existing Application within Azure Active Directory. -> **NOTE:** If you're authenticating using a Service Principal then it must have permissions to both `Read and write all applications` and `Sign in and read user profile` within the `Windows Azure Active Directory` API.

azuread-datasource-azuread-service-princ.body:
data "azuread_service_principal" "$1" {
    # application_id - (Optional) The ID of the Azure AD Application for which to create a Service Principal.
    application_id = ""

    # object_id - (Optional) The ID of the Azure AD Service Principal.
    object_id = ""

    # display_name - (Optional) The Display Name of the Azure AD Application associated with this Service Principal.
    display_name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The Object ID for the Service Principal.
    # "display_name" - (Optional) The Display Name of the Azure AD Application associated with this Service Principal.
}
azuread-datasource-azuread-service-princ.description: Gets information about an existing Service Principal associated with an Application within Azure Active Directory. -> **NOTE:** If you're authenticating using a Service Principal then it must have permissions to both `Read and write all applications` and `Sign in and read user profile` within the `Windows Azure Active Directory` API.

azuread-resource-azuread-application.body:
resource "azuread_application" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The display name for the application.
    name = ""

    # homepage - (Optional) (optional) The URL to the application's home page. If no homepage is specified this defaults to `https://{name}`.
    homepage = ""

    # identifier_uris - (Optional) A list of user-defined URI(s) that uniquely identify a Web application within it's Azure AD tenant, or within a verified custom domain if the application is multi-tenant.
    identifier_uris = ""

    # reply_urls - (Optional) A list of URLs that user tokens are sent to for sign in, or the redirect URIs that OAuth 2.0 authorization codes and access tokens are sent to.
    reply_urls = ""

    # available_to_other_tenants - (Optional) Is this Azure AD Application available to other tenants? Defaults to `false`.
    available_to_other_tenants = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "application_id" - The Application ID.
    # "oauth2_allow_implicit_flow" - (Optional) Does this Azure AD Application allow OAuth2.0 implicit flow tokens? Defaults to "false".
}
azuread-resource-azuread-application.description: Manages an Application within Azure Active Directory. -> **NOTE:** If you're authenticating using a Service Principal then it must have permissions to both `Read and write all applications` and `Sign in and read user profile` within the `Windows Azure Active Directory` API.

azuread-resource-azuread-service-princip.body:
resource "azuread_service_principal_password" "$1" {
    # end_date - (Required) The End Date which the Password is valid until, formatted as a RFC3339 date string (e.g. `2018-01-01T01:02:03Z`). Changing this field forces a new resource to be created.
    end_date = ""

    # value - (Required) The Password for this Service Principal.
    value = ""

    # service_principal_id - (Required) The ID of the Service Principal for which this password should be created. Changing this field forces a new resource to be created.
    service_principal_id = ""

    # key_id - (Optional) A GUID used to uniquely identify this Key. If not specified a GUID will be created. Changing this field forces a new resource to be created.
    key_id = ""

    # start_date - (Optional) The Start Date which the Password is valid from, formatted as a RFC3339 date string (e.g. `2018-01-01T01:02:03Z`). If this isn't specified, the current date is used.  Changing this field forces a new resource to be created.
    start_date = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The Key ID for the Service Principal Password.
    # "start_date" - (Optional) The Start Date which the Password is valid from, formatted as a RFC3339 date string (e.g. "2018-01-01T01:02:03Z"). If this isn't specified, the current date is used.  Changing this field forces a new resource to be created.
}
azuread-resource-azuread-service-princip.description: Manages a Password associated with a Service Principal within Azure Active Directory. -> **NOTE:** If you're authenticating using a Service Principal then it must have permissions to both `Read and write all applications` and `Sign in and read user profile` within the `Windows Azure Active Directory` API.

azuread-resource-azuread-service-princip.body:
resource "azuread_service_principal" "$1" {
    # application_id - (Required) The ID of the Azure AD Application for which to create a Service Principal.
    application_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The Object ID for the Service Principal.
    # "display_name" - The Display Name of the Azure Active Directory Application associated with this Service Principal.
}
azuread-resource-azuread-service-princip.description: Manages a Service Principal associated with an Application within Azure Active Directory. -> **NOTE:** If you're authenticating using a Service Principal then it must have permissions to both `Read and write all applications` and `Sign in and read user profile` within the `Windows Azure Active Directory` API.
